properties.description:
Downtown Dadeland is understood as one of Greater Miami’s best examples of a thriving, self-sustaining urban core.  The only critical element missing from this bourgening economic and cultural node is an OPEN GREEN SPACE.  

In order to make Downtown Dadeland a true Live, Work and Play community, it must find a venue that would allow local residents to find nearby recreational opportunities they can conveniently engage in.  The connectivity this particular location has to compact development, mixed-use zoning, a diverse population, the Metro Rail, Bus way, M-path and US-1 make this an ideal place to promote sustainable living and effective transit systems, two elements of dire need for the future of Greater Miami.  

All elements within the sketch are interchangeable.    These are all just concepts made to provoke thought.  Most of the elements in this sketch are modifications that are not expensive financially, but would require time and commitment to change current land use policies.

properties.description: My idea to improve this place is to create a park with fitness equipment appropriate for individuals with differing mental and physical abilities, that plays music powered by the use of the fitness equipment.
properties.details: So that people with differing abilities can enjoy a shared community space that promotes physical fitness and culture.

properties.description: Miami River Greenway gap closure/"Pop-up Park" - This satellite image shows a 300-foot gap in the Miami River Greenway on the north bank next to the Miami Avenue bridge.  This is the only missing privately owned north bank section in the 1.7 miles between the mouth of the river and the NW 5th Street bridge.  Developers are required to build segments of the greenway when they construct their projects, but it is not known when this site will be developed.  Partners such as Rails-to-Trails Conservancy, the Miami River Commission, City of Miami, Miami-Dade County and Miami Downtown Development Authority have been meeting and discussing innovative ways to create a “pop-up park” along this section as part of the Public Space Challenge.  We propose working with partners and the private landowner to provide minimum improvements to the parcel to allow for safe public use and continuity until such time as formal development of the greenway occurs in the future.
properties.details: Providing public access across the site in advance of building construction would complete the longest waterfront public space outside of the beaches, leverage the millions of dollars that has been invested in other Miami River Greenway sections and allow safe physical activity each day to thousands of residents, workers and visitors for recreation and practical travel.  It is not shown in the satellite picture, but Miami-Dade County Public Works-Waste Management is currently building the segments on publicly owned land under the Miami Ave bridge to the east and under Metrorail to the west.
properties.infolink: Link, FaceBook posting, Tweet and member outreach to follow.........stay tuned.

properties.description: To have my hand-painted flower pots filled with tropical plants and flowers, intermingled with hand-painted wooden benches, adorn a specific area of Calle 8,  so that the tropical atmosphere of our great city can become become more palpable to the toursists  that visit Little Havana by the bus load each day; as well as create an artistic statement that carries the message of this growing art community.
properties.details: Connect with the Little Havana art community by having a focal point that can start that dialogue, as well as enjoy the beauty of our local plants and flowers.

properties.description: Temporarily install a series of swing sets underneath the Metromover superstructure to reinvigorate a public walkway. This low-cost addition will transform functional civic infrastructure into accessible, stimulating, and playful furniture. The corridor is centrally located and serves as a direct path to Government Center Station—MDT's busiest station. Seamlessly integrated into the existing urban framework the swings will be arranged to preserve easy access through the heavily trafficked corridor while providing a new context for recreation and interaction.
properties.details:
The installation will promote physical activity as well as inject spontaneity and sociability into the commons. The swings could also be further refined to include collective games like Montreal’s 21 Balançoires (21 Swings). 

Idea type: Existing place makeover/Physical activity/Shade and public comfort

properties.description: Health in the Hood, along with their community partners, plans to install a pop-up neighborhood gathering place featuring large-scale mural, community garden, and market in a vacant Brownsville lot. This lot, located at NW 27 Avenue and NW 54 Street, has been vacant for decades.  It is an eyesore to residents, as well as a breeding ground for illegal activity, namely profuse littering and an unsanctioned Saturday flea market. A pop-up exhibit in this unused lot will uplift the neighborhood, inspiring change and providing local residents the opportunity to voice their opinions and visions for the future.
properties.details:
Based on conversations held in Fall 2012, local residents are concerned with the current state of this vacant lot and have many ideas for its transformation.  By providing a temporary neighborhood gathering place featuring art & culture, healthy food options, and economic development opportunities, we hope to inspire residents to see the endless possibilities of the vacant lot at NW 27 Avenue and NW 54 Street. 

The main purpose of the pop-up exhibit is to provide a platform for residents to brainstorm and collaborate on more permanent restoration options.  Drawing inspiration from Candy Chang’s Neighborland, residents can write, draw, speak, and share their ideas for the vacant lot.

The mural will serve as a jumping point for positive change in the neighborhood.  Showcasing the community-chosen Brownsville logo and other elements, this will be a conversation piece, a meeting place, and a beautiful entryway to the community.

 The garden and market will provide residents regular access to fresh fruits and vegetables. Health in the Hood will install up to 20 garden plots for Brownsville children and families to increase access to healthy foods and hands-on community gardening.  Our gardens produce kale, collard greens, spinach, tomatoes, okra, swiss chard, eggplant, green beans, mangos, herbs and much more!  In addition to the fresh local produce, the market will also feature local products and goods to stimulate economic development.  By playing a role in the creation of catalytic positive change, children and families build a connection to their neighbors and neighborhood. 

Our vision is for improved wellness in Brownsville with children and families actively participating in their own community’s journey.  By providing community gardens, public art, business opportunities, health education, and community engagement opportunities, Health in the Hood programs are putting children on the path to healthy futures, giving parents helpful information and creating environments that support healthy choices. 

We hope the creation of a pop-up community gathering space will encourage residents to take steps toward creating positive change.
properties.submitter_name: Health in the Hood + community partners

properties.description: As part of a larger initiative to make fitness fun, convenient and affordable, Miami-Dade County Parks, Recreation & Open Spaces Department, in partnership with The Trust for Public Land, installed an outdoor Fitness Zone® at the Gwen Cherry Park.  It was unveiled on the July 24, 2012.   It could be improved by providing  some protection from the sun for those who want to use the area, while providing shade covering that lets sunlight in.
properties.details:
One of the great things about Miami is that there is year-round sunshine and there are lots of outdoor activities.  The Fitness Zone at Gwen Cherry Park creates a great opportunity for youth and the elderly to use the outdoor equipment to stay healthy and fit.  However, it could be better utilized if there was some protection from the South Florida heat.  Sometimes, the sun makes it too hot to touch the metal equipment.
This issue could be resolved if there was a shade covering for the area.  One suggestion is to provide colorful strips of material, like the ones used on sails, to shade the area while allowing some sunlight in. With shade covering, more seniors will be able to use the Fitness Zone during the day and the youth and their families can use the space in the afternoon and evening.
Also, the Fitness Zone is near the park’s entrance.  If the shade covering is beautiful and colorful, it could also be used to attract and welcome more children and families to the park.

properties.details:
satisfy their need for individual expression! 
Children and adults alike can  surround themselves with art and engage in making it as well. Playing and creating together builds community.

properties.description:
ACTIVATING CONNECTIVITY – A PILOT POP-UP POCKET PARK PROJECT

OUR VISION & INSPIRATION

Active, successful, and iconic public spaces from around the world (Federation Square in Melbourne, Australia; Millennium Park in Chicago, Illinois; Yonge-Dundas Square in Toronto, Canada) have many features in common – access to cultural events and galleries, a breathtaking view, a variety of dining options, and a transportation hub to bring people directly into the space are examples of just a few of the ingredients that create the type of environment which brings a diverse community together.

Downtown Miami, with the Arts & Entertainment District, its Central Business District, and the waterfront area create the existing foundation for much of these basic venues and services. We have the Adrienne Arsht Center for the Performing Arts, American Airlines Arena, Bayside Marketplace, and Bayfront Park. Also in development are the new Perez Art Museum and the new Miami Visitors Center, the Miami Art Museum and the Miami Science Museum going up in Museum Park (formerly known as Bicentennial Park), and the new FEC passenger station in downtown Miami. All of these elements provide the makings for Miami to have an iconic public space that would otherwise require millions of dollars of capital investment to provide the same amenities.

Rather than creating an entirely new public space, let us use the many great things that already exist in downtown Miami and that are already happening and simply connect them. Connectivity, particularly safe, shaded, and comfortable pedestrian connectivity is one of the main challenges Miami continues to face. Basic improvements such as lining this corridor with native Florida shade trees and activating the public spaces between these many venues will encourage social interaction and pedestrian traffic. 

Imagine a Miami where young couple enjoying an afternoon picnic in Bayfront Park, listening to live music from local street performers then decide to walk through a pedestrian walkway along Biscayne Boulevard, fully shaded by Silver Buttonwoods and Gumbo Limbos, all the way up to the Arsht Center to check out what great shows are playing that evening. Along the way, they encounter many other amazing pocket parks where children are playing in the water fountains to stay cool, people are sitting at tables enjoying Cuban coffee and playing chess, and a group of university students are playing salsa music and giving free dance lessons to the public.
properties.details:
OUR TEAM & PROJECT

By activating underutilized public spaces between many of these venues, we can create small pocket parks that make it more inviting and enticing to walk this main corridor and explore its many offerings rather than getting in a car to drive from Point A to Point B and bypassing everything in-between. 

The US Green Building Council Emerging Professionals (USGBC EPs) and the American Institute of Architects Young Architects Forum (AIA – YAF) have joined together in a collaborative effort with members from other great community organizations such as the Urban Land Institute (ULI), Tropical Audubon Society (TAS), Environmental Coalition of Miami and the Beaches (EcoMB), Catalyst Miami, County Commissioners offices, and local businesses to create a pilot pop-up park behind the Stephen P. Clark Government Center. Downtown Miami is an area that has been planned and developed time and time again, but often times by one owner, one developer, one agency – limited collaborative efforts. Our intention was to build a coalition of residents from the community, representing various aspects of our diverse population to give voice to its many members on the most viable and desirable uses of our project space. Catalyst Miami has agreed to connect our group with several other community leaders to discuss how we can engage residents from other areas of Miami and bring them downtown so that it truly becomes a space for many aspects of our diverse cultures and population.

The Stephen P. Clark Government Center employs thousands of people and countless more walk through its doors every day. Yet the park space behind this center is severely neglected, having only been known for the sensitive Tent City protest. With a water fountain, sit-able areas, shade trees, and a Metro station nearby, this pocket park has the potential to be a vibrant space for the community if only it had the right programming.

Our project would be to create a pop-up park installation, similar to that of the Purple Line project, to highlight the various programs and activities that could take place at the park behind Stephen P. Clark Government Center. These ideas could be replicated in other pocket parks along the downtown corridor and in any other space in our Miami community.

Our focus to program this pocket park is “Seeing the Future,” recognizing that Miami is still a very young city and to create a space where art and science collide, where design and the environment meet, where health and innovation intersect. This pop-up parks aims to showcase to Miami residents the possibilities of what our city, of what our community can be in the near and distant future. We want to highlight Miami’s heritage, the various cultures, aspects of the environment, public health awareness, and education and innovation through art.

Examples of programming that our group has developed are interactive art projects such as digital graffiti walls, wall shows like that of the New World Symphony, a monthly film series, revamping the water fountain to be solar powered and motion controlled, creating multi-purpose seating areas, creating a life-sized chess game like the Shore Club in Miami Beach, adding more native trees and art sculptures to provide shade and urban canopy, creating artistic living plant walls, adding bicycle racks to encourage alternative transportation, hosting a local farmer’s market, a book market, free public cultural dance lessons (e.g. swing, salsa, rumba), a space for tai chi or yoga, creating a small kickball or soccer field, and local art, music, or street performers.

A collage of our ideas is shown below and the link below to our wiki-page contains more ideas and details of our space. Our ultimate aim is to start the conversation on how to activate and program pocket parks that will encourage community engagement and social interaction, fostering a more pedestrian-focused, healthy, and sustainable Miami community.
properties.submitter_name: USGBC Emerging Professionals & AIA Young Architects Forum

properties.description: My idea for this space is to deliver Miami’s robust health and fitness culture directly to adults and children in under-served neighborhoods, by creating The Fitness Caravan. This is one possible location.  On a regular schedule, The Fitness Caravan, a converted school bus, will visit “fitness deserts” in Miami, where health facilities and the funding to support them are lacking.  The Caravan will bring fitness equipment, classes for children and adults, and healthy nutrition.
properties.details: The Fitness Caravan will let people become healthier in their own communities, at no cost.  Modeled on the free programming at Bayfront Park, The Fitness Caravan will visit each neighborhood on a regularly scheduled day of the week.  Free afternoon and evening classes will include yoga, capoeira, Zumba and Boot Camp.  Healthy activities and programming for children will be offered while parents participate.  Through a cooperative agreement with local Community Supported Agriculture (CSA) providers, The Fitness Caravan will offer healthy food and nutrition education.  Experience demonstrates that, when we share healthy activities and values across our community, Miami residents appreciate, participate, and benefit.

properties.description: Benches on Brickell Bay- On Brickell Bay Drive there is a BEAUTIFUL walkway along the water, but with no where to sit, read, lounge and linger. My husband and I walk along here, well, he walks, i roll. He pushes me in my wheelchair. I have lived on Brickell for almost 20 years and always wondered why there were no benches on this beautiful path..
properties.details: This would help make our Miami better by encouraging people to stay outside longer and enjoy the fresh air. Having benches would increase community bonding, engagement and gathering. People seem to linger and hang out more when there are places to sit, they don't feel the need to rush on by. Also, for people with mobility issues, having a place to rest is crucial, so benches would be a godsend for the the disabled. I keep imagining Central Park with all the benches for people watching. With all of the high rises in Brickell, having a little area to hang would increase people getting to know their neighbors.

properties.description:
In a September 2012 Metro Atlantic article titled, “Miami, Future Skycrapers: Part 1,” author Kevin Gurley states that between 2002 and 2008, “48 skyscrapers were built” in downtown Miami “increasing the Downtown area’s population by 30,000 people, growing from 39,176 people in 2000 to 71,000 in 2010.”

According to Market Insights prepared by the Miami Downtown Development Authority (DDA) in August 2013, Miami’s Central Business District (CBD) includes a total population of 11,185, of which 9,000 are 25 years of age or older, and have an Average Household Income of $86,848. Consumer expenditures for groceries in the CBD is $20.5 million, yet there are no grocery stores located in the area forcing residents into their cars. In addition, while Bayfont Park lies just east of the CBD, there is little to no connection between the park and its neighboring residents.
properties.details:
“Our Biscayne” endeavors to transform a portion of Biscayne Boulevard into a vibrant space, where friends meet, cultures mix and social exchanges unfold. Our project will utilize two of the median parking lots (lots 2 and 3) along the south section of Biscayne Boulevard between East Flagler and NE 2nd Streets as well as a portion of Bayfront Park. 

Each Saturday, one of the lots will be converted into a farmers market, giving residents access to fresh produce, reconnecting the community and invigorating local economies. The other lot will be utilized as “Be Active Park,” a pop-up park to keep CBD residents active by serving as a meeting place for run and bike clubs, a place to take pets and turning asphalt into art by dancing to the music of local bands.

“Our Biscayne” will also be connected to Bayfront Park by providing an outdoor lounge where residents can read a book or relax while watching the activities below them at the Farmer’s Market and “Be Active Park.”

 “Our Biscayne” will partner with the DDA and the City of Miami, as well as the Miami Parking Authority, to implement this project. In fact, this is in line with the DDA’s 2025 Downtown Miami Master Plan whose goals include: 
•	Creating Great Streets and Community Spaces,
•	Elevating Our Grand Boulevards to Prominence,
•	and Promoting Transit and Regional Connectivity.

In order to connect the two parking lots and encourage people to interact with both, we propose closing NE 1st Street between the hours of 9 a.m. and 6 p.m. each Saturday. With any public space, accessibility is a key component to its success. Biscayne Boulevard is easily accessible by car, bicycle, the Metromover, the City of Miami Trolley and Miami-Dade County Metorbus service.

As proposers of this project, we have extensive experience working in and with local governments. In addition, our partners have extensive experience and knowledge of building and maintaining sustainable markets.

properties.description:
Family Gardens + Food Forest + Aquaponics (Fish/Veggies) + Education... at the UPG Garden Center in Amelia Earhart Park! 
* Family Gardens for low-income apartment families to grow their own food organically! 200 Families x 70 Sq Ft each.
* Aquaponics (growing Fish + Veggies together): create a demonstration/education facility so we can get started. 
* Food Forest also provides Shade for the "Fruit Loop" Mountain Bike Trail Loop! Plant 100 tropical fruit trees plus papayas, pigeon peas, etc! 
* Education: create a small pavilion for education, so we are sheltered from rain and sun. It would also be used for Nursery projects. 
FYI: The UPG Garden Center already has funding for a well and major Nursery, so additional plantings will be very cost effective!
properties.details:
Low-income families living in apartments need food to eat, and we will provide space for organic gardens, heirloom vegetable seeds, water and education. 
We all need to eat fruit, so let's make this into an asset for the whole community! 
Aquaponics could allow entrepreneurs based at home feed their own neighborhoods! Let's make this possible. 
Knowledge and training are essential to creating lasting and meaningful change, and this site will become a "breeder reactor" serving the whole community.

properties.description: Visually-stimulating and functional shade, seating, lighting, and landscaping are key components to creating a pleasant waiting experience at the Opa-locka Tri-Rail Station as it expands to accommodate the growing number of mass transit users in South Florida.  Opa-locka has begun to embark on an ambitious revitalization strategy that centers the downtown area around the city’s unique collection of Moorish Revival architecture, community-inspired arts and cultural activities, economic development, and accessibility via mass-transit, car, or plane.  The Opa-locka Community Development Corporation (OLCDC) is working together with the South Florida Regional Transportation Authority (SFRTA), City of Opa-locka, Florida Department of Transportation, and artists to ensure that the expanded Tri-Rail station reflects this strategy.  The SFRTA plans to create five new bus bays, solar powered canopies, and charging stations in the new Opa-locka station lot.  Artists, the community, and project team will collaborate on these improvements to create a unique space at the station that celebrates Opa-locka and welcomes visitors to the area.
properties.details: Foremost, the new space will allow mass transit users to wait safely from the elements as waiting periods can be over an hour during off-peak times (evenings, weekends, holidays) and up to forty minutes on weekdays.  The Opa-locka Tri-Rail Station serves approximately 50 trains per weekday and 40 trains per weekend day.  It also services connections to Miami-Dade Transit buses, Tri-Rail Shuttle links, and the free Opa-locka city shuttle.  Artist- and community-designed continuous bus canopies, seating, and other elements to enhance the station will allow commuters to learn about the community’s identity as the space will reflect the collaborative effort.  It also allows the community to develop a sense of pride and take ownership of one of their public amenities by involving them in the creative process.

properties.description:
The Shades of Miami --
An umbrella-ed walkway colorfully and artfully makes a statement about one of Miami's biggest small needs:  shade.
This installation can be done in many places around Downtown Miami, especially the narrower streets that get hit hard by the sun and heat.
properties.details: Enjoy walking, which then leads to people enjoy and interacting far more with their city. Plus, it can double as an artistic urban installation for special events while relaying a clear message about what is needed to make Miami more livable and walkable.

properties.description: MCAD’s location is a prime spot to enliven downtown and encourage others to do the same!   What is a key element in an enlivened downtown?  MUSIC!  ENTERTAINMENT!   We believe that street (or in our case sidewalk) music/entertainment is a key element missing in downtown Miami!  We plan to create regular music, spoken word, and poetry readings on the steps in front of our building—every Friday afternoon!  Built in 1912, the Old Post Office Building’s east façade is a perfect setting for outreach into the neighborhood.   New York, New Orleans, Seattle to name of few have wonderful live performers throughout their cities—it makes the experience of traveling through a city on foot special.  And we have a plethora of talented folks in Miami!
properties.details: Enjoy their walks.  Have a place to stop, sit and relax.  We envision regular programming on a weekly basis for the entertainment of downtowners—residents, commuters and tourists alike— to sit and listen.  We plan to partner with New World School of the Arts, Miami Dade College, BuskerFest, and the Arts & Business Council to give our fantastic local musicians and entertainers their best an opportunity to share their gifts with downtown.   We hope this will inspire other businesses to do the same and maybe even the City of Miami to create a program for buskers, such as the one in New Orleans or Seattle.  This grant would allow us to pay our entertainers!
properties.title: LIVELY STEPS!

properties.description: The innovative Miami Youth Garden, Inc. (MyG) is a nonprofit organization featuring a live, community garden classroom and a proven youth leadership development program called Seed to Harvest.  Church of the Open Door’s Youth Ministry created the garden, including an action plan and budget.  MyG is now a collaborative effort including The Collective Empowerment Group of South Florida (funded the garden through Wells Fargo and CitiBank community beautification grants), neighborhood volunteers and a grant from Joel Osteen Ministries.  We currently need funding for an irrigation system, wrought-iron fence, additional tools and equipment to expand the program and support teachers to impart the Seed to Harvest curriculum.
properties.details: Miami’s youth are the flowers of tomorrow – healthy plants we really need to grow.  MyG targets the underserved, sub-population within an at-risk community of Liberty City.  A Public Space Challenge grant will allow us to expand the promising program. Our goals include teaching age-appropriate leadership skills, deferred gratification and entrepreneurship; establishing a farmers’ market with healthy food choices for Liberty City residents and a built-in revenue stream to sustain programming; create employment and job training opportunities; and then replicate the program throughout Miami-Dade County.
properties.title: Joel Osteen-supported Community Teaching Garden for Liberty City's Future Leaders

properties.description: My idea to improve this place is to reconstructed the basketball court in my area. Its been run down for 5-6 years. It would be very appreciative to see a nice renovated outdoor basketball court to improve this place.
properties.details: So that kids and parents could stay active, to create a physical atmosphere. To bring everyone together in my area as one family to drive away negative altercations.
properties.title: Outdoor Basketball Court

properties.description: The M-Path along US1, between Vizcaya and Dadeland South stations is poorly lit and unsafe. GREENLIGHTS will illuminate that land with a civic art installation that lights up the columns of MetroRail. The installation will literally spotlight public transit, reminding the 100,000 drivers on US1 every day that MetroRail provides an alternative to driving.  It will also promote the future vision of the GreenLink, the grassroots initiative to transform the M-Path into a world-class mobility corridor (walking/biking/exercise path) and linear park (www.thegreenlink.org).   Our rendering is from UM Arch. School's vision plan of the GreenLink proposing new standards for the path: to light, widen, straighten, and add much-needed amenities.
properties.details: Here’s how GREENLIGHTS works:  Each month, a spotlight installation designed by a local artist will uplight a series of 3 sets of MetroRail columns, spanning 300 feet.  Then, each month, the installation moves to a different section of the 8-mile stretch, strategically positioned for the most community impact.  Over a 12-month period, the low cost, high impact, installation will connect to millions of drivers and residents. This year-long installation will open our eyes to “what could be” — reclaiming the underutilized land under MetroRail and turning it into a bright community asset.
properties.title: GREENLIGHTS a 1-month rotating civic art lighting installation underneath MetroRail

properties.description: Downtown is an exciting place – but sometimes you just need a break from the grind.  What if you could go to a place, leave the stress of work, take a break from the noise and escape to a park like no other? Introducing Sound Garden. From sunrise to sunset, CBD professionals, residents and tourists can come together and enjoy this outdoor music lounge. Surrounded by tall tropical foliage, Sound Garden endeavors to transform a portion of Bayfront Park into an audio oasis that will invigorate cultural engagement and civic life. Through a hidden solar audio system, a weekly variety of instrumental music will seamlessly fill the listening area. For now it only exists in our mind…but wouldn't it be cool to bring it to life? With your vote it can
properties.details: Visitors can comfortably lounge, take a break from the office, get inspired to work, meet friends, learn about new music, read, connect with the outdoors and plug in to the community. The musical program will highlight our cultural diversity and feature instrumental: Ambient, Bossa Nova, Classical, Flamenco, Jazz, Lounge and World music. Sound Garden will have a space for special acoustic performances, and will also house a small lending library where book swapping can take place. This audio oasis can serve as a sightseeing attraction or a hidden gem for locals. We would like to partner with Urban Impact Lab to provide shade with its colorful umbrella installation and the DDA, City of Miami and Bayfront Park, to implement the project.
properties.title: Sound Garden @ Bayfront: A Refreshing Audio Experience

properties.description: Create mini “play kits” for a community with limited access to parks and recreational areas.  Kits would include inexpensive equipment for group activities (such as badminton, jump rope, football, and chalk for hopscotch); arts and crafts materials, and detailed steps to deal with permitting, street closures, agreements for using parking lots and other underutilized spaces as play areas.
properties.details: This project would increase recreational opportunities and promote physical activity.  I would also assist residents in navigating city processes and provide a springboard for seeking permanent play spaces. The kits would be piloted in the West Perinne community but can be easily replicated in other communities.
properties.submitter_name: The Health and Built Environment Committee of the Consortium for a Healthier Miami-Dade
properties.title: Play Kits or Park in a Box

properties.description: Skate Free would like to develop the defunct and under used spaced under the I-95 free way at the MPA Lot 11. We would like to create a 40,000 sq. ft mix use skate plaza and green space that offers a useful urban environment promoting physical activity, gathering of families/friends, and community connectivity. Skateboarders and families in Downtown Miami are underserved with public space to play and enjoy. Skate free would like to transform an otherwise neglected piece of land that serves only parking and transform this space into a 50/50 green space and concrete skate plaza that includes a 200 sq. ft sculpture garden, 1000 sq. ft dog park,  2000 sq. ft play ground,  16,800 sq. ft of green space, and a 20,000 sq. ft skatepark.
properties.details: This space sits at the convergence of three Miami neighborhoods including Park West, Overtown and Miami River. This Project will allow kids and their parents to have a safe and shaded place to skateboard, play, have picnics or outings, walk their dogs and enjoy the sculpture of local miami artists. The plaza serves the community directly by being locate within a quarter mile of the Government Center Metro Rail, Mover and Bus station and it is accessible from the I-95 North 2nd AVE Exit and the I-95 South NW 8th ST Exit with available parking at MPA lot 12 and 13. People will be able to safely monitor their kids while they are playing out doors and exercising while being under the shade of the I-95 Overpass. This park will be free and public
properties.title: Lot 11 Green Space Skate Plaza

properties.description: is to create the first truly handicapped accessible beach.  Miami-Dade County touts its beaches, saying that people with disabilities are welcome. In truth, some beaches have wheelchair mats, but they end far short of the main beach area.  We are proposing to create the first fully accessible beach to be located on 76th Street in Miami Beach. A wheelchair mat would extend further into the sand, configured to create a patio landing.  We would purchase special assistive beach chairs and aquatic equipment including adaptive kayaks, wave skis, and flotation devices. The project organizer is the Sabrina Cohen Foundation, a non-profit dedicated to providing a better quality of life for people living with paralysis.
properties.details: fully enjoy the physical, recreational and spiritual benefits of the beach, including the disabled. This fully accessible beach area would enable disabled people to get onto the sand. People in wheelchairs could hang out in the patio area with their friends, bask under umbrella-topped assistive device beach chairs, roll along the shoreline, and enjoy the spray of the waves. Those with assistance could use the specialized aquatic equipment. Such a beach would foster friendships between able-bodied and disabled people, promote tourism, and serve as a model for other county beaches. This accessible beach could be a stand-alone project or could be part of an adaptive gym project that SCF is discussing with the City of Miami Beach.
properties.title: Beach for ALL

properties.description: Create  therapeutic interactive, outdoor learning spaces at the Arcola Lakes branch library. Equip with Wi-Fi, nature-based play equipment and outdoor speakers to create a family friendly environment for people to gather. Invite community members to specially designed programming that increases awareness of the joy and benefits of living in South Florida
properties.details: This neighborhood has a highly utilized public library that attracts customers of all age levels and interests. On most days, the building itself is filled to capacity, illustrating the need to expand the library's footprint and create a multi-functional, outdoor space that will enhance the community's experience. With the Wi-Fi, users can sit in the "park" and still have access to online resources while the facility is closed. Programmatically, outdoor theater, yoga and tai-chi can become  regularly scheduled events.
properties.title: Your Library Outdoors

properties.description: Install several bike repair stations and public bike pumps in strategic locations across Miami.
properties.details:
To make Miami more bike friendly! People can bike anxiety-free knowing that if they get a flat tire, a public bike pump will be nearby... or if their seat gets loose, they can tighten it at a repair station... and so on!

More bikers= less cars= less traffic!
properties.title: BIKE REPAIR and PUMP STATIONS

properties.description: Bringing back the old school Hot Wheels Monday night roller skate funk and taking it to downtown’s Pepper Fountain at Bayfront Park!  Every second Monday night of the month, Bay Skate Mondays will transform downtown’s CBD into a community gathering space that celebrates a Miami pastime which brings together different cultures, ages and favorite freestyle moves.  With the abundant seating, smooth surface and bay views, Pepper Fountain is the perfect venue for a unique social experiment. We will introduce Bay Skate Mondays by inviting the original Hot Wheels DJ Irie, and complete the experience with everything from skate rentals and shoe valet to food trucks and first aid stations.
properties.details: Bay Skate Mondays is a great excuse for the community to come together and have fun! By activating this underutilized portion of Bayfront Park, we’ll emphasize the city’s iconic water feature and bay front views. We will bring people to the park at night and to the downtown area to patronize local businesses and restaurants.  By giving residents access to a roller rink, we’ll encourage them to become active and live more healthy social lifestyles.
properties.submitter_name: Macias Advertising / Walk Landscape and Urban Design
properties.title: Bay Skate Mondays

properties.description: Plant and maintain 10 gardens on swales at strategic corners throughout La Paloma, a culturally-mixed neighborhood in northern, unincorporated Miami-Dade. Each garden will cultivate flowers, fruits, and vegetables, and will surround a trash can, a recyling bin, and a compost bin. Soaring over the garden, in lieu of a scarecrow, will be a sculpture of a dove created by neighborhood youth in collaboration with local artists.
properties.details: The La Paloma Garden Walk would promote health and community in the La Paloma neighborhood. In a neighborhood without a public park, the garden walk will inspire residents to get out of the house and explore, activating the sidewalks as public and recreational space. Designated families on each block would maintain the gardens, in collaboration with their neighbors. The caretakers would also manage the trash, recycling, and compost bins, keeping trash off the streets and enriching the soil. The vegetable and fruits would be shared by all, whether casually picked by passersby or harvested by the community. The doves would stand as a symbol of neighborhood pride.
properties.title: La Paloma Garden Walk

properties.description: West Kendall Baptist Hospital (WKBH) wants to foster a sense of place and create a gathering spot for residents to enjoy cultural and recreational activities.  The hospital's park-like grounds currently contain a walking trail and several small lakes. With additional funding, the hospital plans to develop a “Fitness Zone,” install lighting to improve safety and encourage use of the site,  construct a permanent stage for community events including live entertainment, and seek a park designation. Public Space Challenge funds would support the fitness trail, which will be designed to appeal to the elderly, accommodate cyclists and runners, and promote a more comprehensive fitness experience for walkers.
properties.details:
As a community hub, the hospital's planned park would inspire people to incorporate exercise into their daily routine; help connect them to their neighbors and to resources that can prevent heart disease, obesity and other ailments; and change lives to be healthier, happier and longer.

Since the hospital's opening, West Kendall residents have used the grounds and beautiful paths around the lakes for their daily exercise, to bring their elderly family members outdoors for fresh air or to take their babies for a stroll around the gardens. The proximity of schools and residences makes WKBH an ideal location to gather and connect with neighbors, a critical element in creating a sense of community.
properties.title: Living Healthy in West Kendall: Connecting, Inspiring, Changing Lives

properties.description: Add low-cost low tech signs along the trail that will let people know how long and how far a location destination is (ie. AD Barnes Park, 5 mi, 1200 ft).
properties.details: The Ludlam Trail is a 6.2 mile corridor runs through the heart of Miami-Dade County, and together with the M-Path and South Dade Trail, would form an uninterrupted regional trail network from Homestead to Downtown Miami to Flagami. It directly connects to 4 schools, 3 major regional parks, and dozens of neighborhoods, and will reach over 34,000 residents who live within ½ mile.  Making sure people know how to get there, and how far/ long it will take to get to key destinations is a great way to make the trail an amenity, while long term planning for the corridor continues.
properties.title: Ludlam Trail walking signs

properties.description: When I visit our parks, I see a mess of bottles, cans, plastic bags—remnants of people enjoying parks just left there. But people aren’t all to blame. We haven’t made it easy.  There are NO recycling bins in our parks—the very places where people gather to have BBQs, where they bring bottles and cans by the car load  have no alternative but to throw them away in overfilled trash cans which easily blow over and into our waterways.  Additionally, for those conscientious enough to bring their own bottles, there are no purposefully designed refill stations as I have seen in airports and parks at major cities all over the world.   Let’s add recycle bins and water bottle refill stations to popular parks where people gather and exercise.
properties.details: Recycle their waste responsibly and cut down on single use plastics (especially plastic water bottles) by giving them an alternative to trash cans and an option to refill their drinking bottles from stations designed for that purpose. There are a variety of ways to design these so that they are fun (some recycle bins make music when you recycle) or have messages conveying the importance of recycling and reducing waste.  Stations can be designed as a water bottle refill and drinking fountain hybrid with counters that track impact by # plastic bottles saved. Both can be branded ( like the coca cola recycling bins on Lincoln road) or have space for advertising to help defray the costs and scale the project to cover more parks in the future.
properties.title: Water Bottle Refill Stations and Recycling Bins in Parks

properties.description: is to set up a free library  on the metro rail platforms to promote literacy. The library would also provide more attractive seating and serve to improve the quality of public transit.
properties.details: have a more positive experience riding the metro rail.
properties.title: Metro-Rail Transit Library

properties.description: Create the Wynwood Community Market at the Bakehouse Art Complex, a 28 year old artist colony housing 60 artists’ studios on a 2.3 acre(100,188 sq.ft.) parcel located at NW 32nd Street & NW 6th Ave. The market will prominently feature South Florida farm-to-table produce; Wynwood- and Miami-produced craft foods and products; herbs, flowers and other plants; and products by local producers (such as Wynwood Brewing, Sprout Floral, Bunnie Cakes). Other activities of interest to the community will include free yoga, artist booths, crafts, performances, and activities and hands-on crafts for kids. The market will be held monthly on Second Saturday from noon-6pm for the first six months; moving to twice monthly on the second and fourth Saturdays.
properties.details: The Wynwood Community Market will be conceived by and for the residents and businesses of Wynwood. If market visitors want cooking demonstrations, then we will work to find partner organizations that can provide this service. The market will celebrate and attract the diversity of Wynwood (different generations, cultures, socio/economic backgrounds). It will have a block-party feel, offering market goers a multitude of experiences both inside and around the grounds and surrounding areas of the BAC. The atmosphere will be both communities enriching and enriched (home-grown). The BAC wishes to create a place where neighbors can gather together and as an arts center we are already well-positioned to serve Wynwood in this capacity.
properties.title: Wynwood Community Market at Bakehouse Art Complex

properties.description:
The stair installation is proposed with the premise of promoting the use of the stair vs the escalator in our public transportation stations, such as the metro mover and metro rail.  This idea not only improves the design quality by using art, but also expresses an educational message to create awareness among our pedestrians of the health benefits of physical activity, even when just going up a few stairs.
This project will be organized by A.L.T. (Active Living Team) Non-profit organization with the support of local artists, architects and community organizers.
properties.details: The project will help people become aware of the advantages of modifications in their physical activity patterns, and how utilizing the stair in their daily commute will help create large scale well being benefits throughout their life.  The project can be temporary, permanent or constantly interchanging installations to maintain the commuter engaged and excited about making the stairs a permanent part of their routine and life style.
properties.title: The Public Stair Activation

properties.description:
A large, grassy median space at NE 2nd Ave and NE 62nd Street in Little Haiti is barren except for a lone bus stop bench. This highly trafficked intersection is strategically positioned across from Notre Dame D’Haiti – an iconic Catholic church that attracts parishioners from throughout Miami-Dade and Broward, and tourists – and the Little Haiti Soccer Stadium. It sits along the main artery connecting I-95 to Biscayne Boulevard and serves as a main hub for bus riders. Easily seen by thousands and visited by hundreds a day, this median is primed to become an important corner of Little Haiti.

NE2P is joining Miami Mountains Foundation to develop A y ï t i, land of high mountains, an art intervention plan to redesign the Median landscape and incorporate a large-scale, walk- through, polychrome iron sculpture of the beautiful mountains in Haiti by kinetic artist Miguel Prypchan, in memory of victims of the Haiti earthquake. The redesigned Median offers additional comfortable seating and shading in the area for pedestrians, church and park-goers, and bus riders, and provides additional greenery and color in an otherwise overlooked lot.

Like the beautified Toussaint L’ouverture park at NE 62nd St and N. Miami Avenue, this project will transform a barren lot into an engaging landscape that will inspire a sense of pride in local residents and business owners. The Ayïti sculpture and median landscape will become a healthy artistic landmark for Little Haiti community and Miami.
properties.details: Our goal is to transform an overlooked but important public space in Little Haiti, into a useful, and beautiful artistic landscape for local residents, commemorating more than 250,000 lives lost in the Haiti earthquake in 2010, and inspiring Miamians to recognize the impact of the Haitian culture on our local community.
properties.short_description: To transform an underused road median in Little Haiti with vibrant public art and amenities for the community, in memory of victims of the Haiti earthquake.
properties.title: A y ï t i, land of high mountains by Miami Mountains Foundation

properties.description: The idea is to expand the El Portal Nature Trail by taking down a fence that separates the trail from Horace Mann Middle School and work with the District to take over an additional 40 by 600 feet of seldom used field space.  This expansion would convert this trail from a 15,000 square foot space, to a community park of almost 40,000 square feet. The trail would be extended into the new area to create a loop with outdoor exercise equipment, water refill station and tree ID signs. Currently, the trail is dilapidated, seldom used and includes several invasive tree species. The expanded park would include a reflection area where students and residents of all ages could come to experience the sounds of nature in this unique oasis.
properties.details: So that the community can come together to walk, run, exercise with the equipment or just sit and contemplate nature.  It would be a place of learning about native plants and animals where parents could bring their kids to enjoy the outdoors. It would make Miami better with a creative solution to expanding and enhancing our green spaces in a cost-effective way that can be replicated in other municipalities.  Combining the City resources with that of the school district, we can achieve a beautiful greenspace that benefits everyone in the area.  The inclusion of a reflection area is a great place for neighbors to sit and talk while relaxing on benches under the trees.  The increase in activity would refocus attention on this community space.
properties.short_description: To expand El Portal's nature trail located next to Horace Mann Middle School into a larger park with native trees, exercise equipment, a meditation garden and a water station.
properties.title: Nature Trail Community Park

properties.description: The NMPD seeks to redevelop Oleander Park located at 12100 NW 13 Avenue. As an underutilized public park, the Department would like to convert the space into a multi-use park with four main components: a K-9 Training Facility for North Miami PD and surrounding agency K-9 units; a Tot-lot; a mini-dog park; and a community garden.  These lush green spaces fully engage the community in a safe place and allow police officers, residents, and children to interact with each other in a positive way.
properties.details: Enhancing an often forgotten park and segment of the City, increases the residents pride and interaction within their neighborhood. The K-9 Facility allows for visibility and consistent interaction by the officers within the community. With virtually no separation, aside from fencing, between the officers and the community, relationships and trust will be forged at the footsteps of their homes. Children along with their families and animals, have a fully integrated space  to enjoy  outdoor activities. The organic synergy of the space continues in the community garden; planted and harvested by the residents and the officers. This rehabilitated space is a living classroom breading hope for an engaged, active, and healthy community.
properties.short_description: To convert Griffing Community Center's park into a tot-lot, mini-dog park, k-9 training facility for North Miami PD, and a community garden.
properties.title: North Miami K-9 Facility  and Community Park

properties.description: The formula for ‘FoodSpark: Miami’ (FSM) is simple in concept: Public Space + Art + Music + Miami Residents + Food + Conversation. This idea - inspired by an initiative that began in St. Louis, MO last year - is for a monthly event creating spaces open to the public, where diverse groups of people can come together to bond over food & topics of discussion they care about. FSM would also incorporate visual/performance art & music. To launch FSM, we envision starting in a place easily accessible by mass transit and centrally located within Miami-Dade County, such as Museum Park. From there, FSM would partner with organizations in various neighborhoods, and travel to different locations each month in order to reach as many people as possible.
properties.details: Miami-Dade County is known for being home to a diverse population of individuals who represent a myriad of racial and ethnic backgrounds; however, too often our diverse community tends to live and work in silos, making it difficult to regularly interact with one another in meaningful ways. ‘FoodSpark: Miami’ (FSM) is about providing more opportunities for the people of greater Miami to connect in a fun way they wouldn’t usually be able to in public places. Each month, FSM will provide another space fostering new relationships between residents who may have never met each other, as well as cultivating ideas to bridge our culturally-rich neighborhoods together despite our geographic separation.
properties.short_description: To provide creative gathering space for Hialeah residents to discuss important social issues with fellow citizens and key leaders in an interactive, refreshing way via food and conversation.
properties.title: FoodSpark: Miami - Creative Gatherings Connecting Miamians via Food & Conversation!

properties.description: To construct lively and innovative bus shelters that will bring attention to the lack of bus shelters throughout Miami-Dade. Today, over 2,000 bus stops across the county are uncovered. Transit-dependent commuters must endure Miami’s torrential downpours and heat just to get to work or school and back.  We will design and construct bus shelters at key locations using a design consistent with each neighborhood’s style, and that addresses the challenges limiting the construction of shelters, such as limited space. Each shelter will have a call-to-action for the public to submit their own design solutions.
properties.details: Feel comfortable and safe while waiting for their bus, while enhancing the eccentric beauty of Miami-Dade. This project will facilitate the installation of much needed shelters by tapping into the public’s breadth of expertise and creativity, and expediting the design process. It will also inform potential advertisers of the value of investing in public bus shelters. We will draw attention to the needs of transit-dependent commuters, and publicize a virtual charrette where citizens can provide feedback on the design and special amenities of future bus shelters.
properties.short_description: To build a lively bus shelter that highlights the need for more bus shelters in Miami-Dade County followed by an online campaign to improve bus stops throughout the county.
properties.submitter_name: Office of Miami-Dade County Commissioner Xavier Suarez
properties.title: Top Them Off

properties.description: We will bring the successful model of Jazz in the Gables lunchtime jazz concerts to the community in and around the Jackson Healthcare complex.
properties.details: Our lunchtime jazz concerts (more than 60 successfully produced on the plaza of the Coral Gables Museum) are a free respite in the workday for people to relax, eat lunch, and be entertained with high-quality music.
properties.short_description: To bring regular lunchtime jazz concerts to the community in and around the Jackson Healthcare complex.
properties.title: More jazz for more people

properties.description: Residents need a green space to bring their families to 365 days a year, whether it is to picnic, sit enjoy nature, spot butterflies or birds or enjoy free community programming.  The Greenhouse is an all-in-one solution to all of these needs.   Our goal is for people to connect with nature and enjoy the elements of earth, wind, water and sun.  We realize shade is a valuable commodity.Our solution for shade is innovative and sustainable. We will use photovoltaic (solar) panels in a decorative pattern on the roof to provide shade for park-goers while using clean sustainable energy technology, and to draw upon the planet’s most plentiful and widely distributed renewable energy source: the sun.
properties.details: We want people to enjoy the space, and feel happy and healthy in this outdoor oasis.  The solar panels will provide shade near the 50-foot stage, so the audience can enjoy performances in the day and night.  We will program the Park with diverse free content including music concerts, artsy events, yoga, and green discussions for kids, families and adults of every generation. It is critical we offer shade to avoid the dangerous effects of sunburn and as a measure for their experience to be cool and enjoyable, especially in the summer months. We hope people will learn more about sustainable energy solutions, and become inspired to bring this to their homes, businesses and communities.
properties.short_description: To install solar panels on the roof of the soon-to-be built Wynwood Greenhouse park, which will offer shade while harnessing solar energy to power lighting at night and a sound system for concerts.
properties.title: Wynwood Greenhouse is an innovative outdoor destination intersecting art, architecture and nature.

properties.description: Hundreds of students cross the intersection on Miller/SW 56 Street and SW 162 Avenue on weekdays to go to John A. Ferguson High School while thousands more drive down this major corridor weekly. Let's change the streetscape and activate this space not only with public art but also with famous lines of poetry in the crosswalk! I want to have a contest at Ferguson High School and have the students submit their favorite lines of poetry. The top voted lines of poetry will be incorporated into the surrounding crosswalks. As Robert Frost said, "I have never started a poem yet whose end I knew. Writing a poem is discovering." I want to create a memorable place for all residents; walking through a poem is discovering, too.
properties.details: I want to add poetry in our crosswalks so that people can experience something more than what our streets currently offer-- sidewalks, medians, street lamps, roadways. We have residents who walk, jog, run, rollerblade and bike and they should be able to experience art and poetry as other areas do in Miami-Dade County. When residents walk from one neighborhood to the next, they should have a memorable and discovering experience. This project would create and activate this corridor.
properties.short_description: To activate a crosswalk with public art and poetry by famous authors and students in West Miami.
properties.submitter_name: Office of Miami-Dade County Commissioner Juan C. Zapata
properties.title: Walking a poem is discovering - poetry in the crosswalk

properties.description: Currently, there are several acres of parking lots/grassy spaces located directly outside the North Dade Health Center & the Miami Gardens Neighborhood Enrichment Center located at 16405/165555 NW 25th Avenue in the Bunche Park neighborhood of Miami Gardens. Very little $$ would be required  to upgrade this easily accessible area into a vibrant public space which may function as a  parking lot for the community centers during the day (M-F 9-5), but would be a cool pop-up  cultural hub after hours and on wknds when the health/community centers are closed to the public. Examples of improving the space would be to work with our urban design/landscape architecture team to  provide better lighting,  install more public seating/tables, etc.
properties.details: Our team  would love to work w/ the City of Miami Gardens in transforming this relatively under-utilized public space in Bunche Park into a cutting-edge cultural innovation hub where  highly acclaimed educators & health professionals, business leaders, and professional designers and artists from around the world could partner WITH  residents of Miami Gardens in order to develop and implement truly innovative inter-cultural, inter-generational,  interactive cultural arts outreach programs and projects in order to cultivate a healthier, more civically engaged and socially-conscious urban neighborhood. This particular project would serve as a pilot community project for several other cultural collaboratories to be created in the United States.
properties.short_description: To transform the unused outdoors area of the Bunche Park Community Center in Miami Gardens into a hub for cutting-edge outreach projects.
properties.title: Bunche Park Community Collaboratory

properties.description:
In Miami's early days when black performers came to town and played on Miami Beach, they had to be back on the mainland before curfew at 12 midnight. They would go to Overtown and perform for the residents of Overtown, usually with out charging or being paid, at local venues or even on the street. 

I propose pop up performances in various venues and street corners that bring the music back and educate today's Miami residents about the rich musical legacies that graced our city in its early days using today's local performers.
properties.details: Miami is often portrayed as not having an identify of culture and history. So many that live here do not know of the hidden gems and therefore they lack a "sense of place". Children, in particular, would benefit from learning of what their neighborhoods have been, while enriching the experience with performances that resonate with today's artistic aesthetic.
properties.short_description: To bring musical performances to Overtown that engage the community around the neighborhood's musical history.
properties.title: Tribute to Overtown's Musical History, Late Late Shows

properties.description: Redesign the Miami skyline with NEWT, an art & sound installation to temporarily replace the dancing silhouette on the InterContinental's 19-story digital canvas in Fall 2015. Inspired by Isaac Newton's theory that each primary color correlates to a note on the musical scale, we designed a series of dynamic projections to play on the hotel's wall in synchrony with an original composition streamed live online.  For 5 days everyone will have access to this sensorial narrative from public lookout points throughout the city.  NEWT uses everyday technology to celebrate public art, augmented architecture & transmedia. NEWT will also come alive through compelling programming, including thematic events & activations in local spaces in the district.
properties.details: NEWT will broaden exposure to contemporary art, technology and performative architecture.  The art experience is immersive, sensorial & reflective.  People will be taken on an emotional journey designed to tap specific visual and audio cues through color, light and sound; and will also be mobilized to explore related events, panel discussions and activations taking place in the area.  Based on themes of color and sound; public art and augmented architecture; Downtown Miami’s role in the city’s cultural identity; and the intersection between technology and art, NEWT's programming will enlighten younger and newer audiences. NEWT appeals to audiences across gender, language, race, education, socio-economic status and arts sensitivities.
properties.short_description: To host community events surrounding an art project 19-stories high on the Intercontinental Miami with animations in brilliant color & light in synchrony with original music streamed online.
properties.title: NEWT Miami

properties.description: The Homestead Air Reserve Park is the perfect location for enjoying the great South Florida outdoors.  The open fields and beautiful trees lend themselves to the wonderful game of Discgolf.  The park is already properly maintained and is mostly used by a few folks for walking and jogging, leaving this land mostly empty.  The improvement will be found by giving this park purpose and appeal.  The area is growing fast .  The park is large enough to accommodate more than one 18 'hole' course plus some practice areas. Discgolf is low-cost to build and maintain since all the equipment is rugged and intended for prolonged outdoor use.
properties.details: This idea will help improve the quality of life of an area that this growing  fast and thirsting for activities.  Discgolf is low-cost to enjoy, is playable by people of all ages and is played throughout the world.  Travelers are already attracted to the Keys, Biscayne National Park, Everglades, etc.  This could be one more stop or the jumping off point for outdoor fun.  People from everywhere will have another great reason to head to South Florida!
properties.short_description: To create a new discgolf course and club that will host community activities at the underutilized Homestead Air Reserve Park.
properties.title: Homestead Air Reserve Park (HARP) Discgolf Course

properties.description:
To jumpstart the Vibe305 Café to support Empowered Youth! Currently, the county is leasing this property to EY to expand their successful Vibe 305 food truck concept into a fully operational café.  Currently the land is sitting empty and represents one of the last green spaces in Wynwood. 

We would like to set up an outdoor garden and picnic space with wifi access for anyone in the neighborhood that would provide some shade, some rest, and a space to connect - both on the web and with each other. 

Everything supported by this effort is already part of the final café design - and who knows? the food truck may stop by to serve lunch!

Costs: $2,500-electricity + wifi; $3,000- landscaping + furniture; $1,000-gravel; $2,000-labor
properties.details:
Change lives.  Simply stated, creating jobs for our inner-city youth transforms and saves lives. 

This project will create an outdoor public green space in Wynwood and it will serve as a link between the 'new creative' class of Miami that is rapidly growing around Wynwood and Midtown and the young urban youth who are have yet to connect to the 'new' Miami. 

The Vibe 305 Cafe will be a training kitchen for our young men and present them with certification in the culinary basics. They will get their on-the-job training and work experience on the Vibe 305 food truck or in the Vibe 305 Cafe.  hey will learn a work ethic, responsibility, accountability, and customer relations skills. They will leave our program ready for success.
properties.short_description: A partnership with Trinity Episcopal Catheral to create a new public space with free wi-fi, natural shade and a local, edible garden that will also host the Vibe 305 food truck and job training initiative.
properties.title: Vibe 305 Public Garden and Hot Spot

properties.description: Starting with the rooftop of the Miami-Dade College parking garage, GrooveMiami is a series of multi-style, group dance classes. GrooveMiami will repurpose locations like the MDC parking garage through hour to hour and a half guided mini-classes in styles including salsa, swing, line dancing, and disco yoga for a cool down!
properties.details: Get out, move, and groove! GrooveMiami will help people to come together and reap the health benefits of an hour to an hour and a half of moderate-intensity cardiovascular exercise. And, by targeting multiple public spaces across Miami-Dade ranging from the roof top of the Miami-Dade College parking garage downtown to Metrorail stops to public parks, GrooveMiami also hopes to broaden participants' understanding of how and to what ends public space can be used.
properties.short_description: To run a pop-up dance party series that promotes fitness and connection through multi-style mini classes in spaces throughout Miami.
properties.title: GrooveMiami

properties.description:
The Miami River is a significant artery for the city. With ships frequently passing, vehicular traffic, cyclists, and pedestrians alike, must yield to the rhythms of the opening bridges. These vertical surfaces are untapped canvases for creative urban works.

As a way to make an engaging experience for those waiting to cross the Miami River, I propose to project haiku* on the vertical faces of the Brickell avenue bridge each time it opens in the evening. These visual short texts would be submitted by the public through an online platform, and explore the subject of water.

Drawbridge Projections would utilize an existing infrastructural element in the heart of the city, and transform it into a dynamic community-generated art project.
properties.details:
This proposal would allow the public to reflect upon a unified theme, and soften a moment of tension for traffic within the city fabric. The drawbridges are in place because of water, and have the potential to be used as a stage to celebrate it!

*Haiku (俳句 high-koo) are short poems with a simple text structure that capture a fleeting moment, feeling, or image. They are often inspired by natural elements or the surrounding urban environment, and can reflect both humor and emotion.
properties.short_description: To project poems submitted by Miamians on the NE 2 Ave drawbridge at the Miami River during rush hour in the winter months - transforming it into a dynamic, community-generated art project.
properties.title: Drawbridge Projections: Thoughts on Water

properties.description: A small neighborhood park should become a gathering place for inter-generational activities. The informal adult  gathering place is situated on a distressed commercial corridor where children from two elementary schools pass by everyday. The park needs to become a more formal gathering where children and adults are able to use free wifi internet access. The park should also become a catalyst for creating more green space in the area.
properties.details:
use the park as a place to improve the aesthetic look and feel of the neighborhood, increase interactions between adults and children in the community; spur redevelopment along the commercial corridor and link the schools to the community in a positive way.
Additional we would like to use a near by building a a small community arts center that would attract local artist to the community and provide opportunities for children to learn history, art and culture on a safe space.
properties.short_description: To transform Broadway Park, a small community park in Liberty City, into a green, safe community space that will spur intergenerational arts and cultural activities.
properties.title: NW 18th Ave --Making Connections Project with Partners in Progress Initiative

properties.description: This space runs from NE 1st St to NE 4th St under the Metromover.  The idea is to formalize and improve the existing path, provide elements to make it more welcoming.  Add simple easy to maintain and pleasant landscaping.  Add doggie bag holders so dog walkers can clean up after their pups.
properties.details: Enjoy an area that is currently blighted, by making the space open and welcoming.  Formalizing a space that is currently used as a dog walking space.
properties.short_description: To open a blighted space under a section of the metromover that will allow for a formal walking path, landscaping, and dog waste stations.
properties.title: Metromover Parkway

properties.description: Transform underutilized outdoor green space in the Jackson Memorial Hospital Campus into a healing garden.
properties.details:
...rejuvenate from their daily stresses. Patients, specially, need a space of refuge outside of the hospital to escape their daily health stresses. Several studies have proven that patients with access to nature will heal faster than those without access to nature. The Jackson Memorial Hospital campus is undesirably urban and devoid of green space. A quiet space of refuge, where one’s senses are completely immersed in nature is desperately needed. The garden will be designed for patients, but will also be used and appreciated by patient families, hospital staff and the public.

This will be a collaboration between Landscape Architects and University of Miami Medical Students.
properties.short_description: To transform vacant outdoor space in the Jackson Memorial Hospital campus into a healing garden for patients, and the public.
properties.title: Garden for Healing

properties.description: …will create an emotional connection with our residents, a sense of community & an atmosphere everyone can enjoy. As Peter Kageyana, author of For the Love of Cities, says “You can fill every pothole, but you get no love for filling potholes.”  We may not be able to solve Miami’s transit system, but we can create shade and a “fun” bond through haikus with residents on their journeys around Miami. Through Million Trees Miami, Neat Streets Miami and Commissioner Zapata’s dedication to trees & beautification, this project involves planting canopy trees & stenciling haikus about trees (contest winners) at 10 bus stops on Kendall Drive, a major east-west corridor in District 11.  We will submit to IOBY’s “Trick Out My Trip!” as a possible match.
properties.details: …enjoy their commute between where they live, work, & play.   Haikus stenciled on sidewalks in front of bus benches will create an emotional connection to Miami.  In line with the West End Connectivity Master Plan, which Commissioner Zapata developed in partnership with several County departments, canopy trees beautify corridors, create cooler temperatures, & protect bus riders from the elements, allowing commuters to be more comfortable while waiting for their bus.  “By greening Miami-Dade with trees, we’re creating attractive gateways, enhancing our quality of life and beginning a legacy that lasts generations,” said Neat Streets Miami Chairman Commissioner Moss.  The bottom line, we want to cultivate a love for trees!
properties.title: Growing Green Bus Stops

properties.description:
My idea is to bring entertainment to West Kendall, an area flooded by residential homes and not much in the form of entertainment for locals without needing to drive 5 or 10 plus miles away. 
I propose a concert series that showcases local talent, this would make use of a large open undeveloped area at the heart of our community that is perfect for a stage, foodtrucks and families.

Very similar to the Noches Tropicales concert series already being done by the Parks Foundation in different parks of Miami-Dade County.
properties.details:
Have entertainment for the locals by the locals, and generate interest from all parts of Miami to come visit West Kendall. 
This would provide close local entertainment that locals could walk, bike, or drive to without needing travel a far distance.
properties.title: West End Concert Series

properties.description:
The West End Bus Terminal is an excellent piece of transit infrastructure; however its impact can be significantly magnified if a few lite enhancements are made to the station.  Most important is the addition of a transit kiosk which are currently located at metro rail stations, but none located on the west side of the county.  Next, is the addition of a bike pump/repair station and covered bike parking to better serve bike commuters. Third, is the installation of public art that celebrates the culture of the surrounding 
community to make the station more welcoming to patrons.
properties.details: Have an improved quality of life for those who already use the bus station, and encourage those in the community who are sick of driving to realize the benefits of transit. The West Kendall area has been enduring some of the longest commute times in the entire county for the past 20 years.  The West End Bus Terminal already services numerous bus routes that connect to multiple destinations including various schools, parks, Dadeland Mall, Miami-Dade College, Town & Country Mall, West Kendall Baptist Hospital, and more.  Let’s make this bus terminal serve as bench mark of what other bus stations in Miami-Dade County should strive for!
properties.title: West End Bus Station Enhancement

properties.description: is to transform Riverside Park into a safe family destination filled with water games during summertime weekends. Riverside Park is located in the heart of Little Havana, over 13,000 youth and children live within one mile of the park. The park is currently underutilized, the proposed idea is to bring neighbors back to the park by offering a summer of cool and exciting water themed experiences reminiscent of spontaneous block parties in cities such as New York and Chicago on scorching hot summer days. This could include activities such as water balloons, slip and slides, inflatable water slides, fire trucks, water bottle relay races and many more activities.
properties.details: The objective is for residents to reclaim Riverside Park by encouraging fun interaction that builds community.  In a neighborhood where the crime rate is high residents are eager to connect, bond, and reclaim “contested” spaces. The purpose is to create vibrancy in the space and transform the park into a place where children can play, families can interact, and the neighborhood grows stronger.   This is also an opportunity for parents and neighbors to take an active part in planning and implementing activities in the park. This is a sustainable neighborhood and placed based activity that is  low-cost and should be resident led and implemented.
properties.title: Fiestas de Agua

properties.description: The walkway surrounding the JFK Library building has been unutilized for a number of years. Adding creative, artistic seating areas along the walkway such as concrete cubes and a hammock area will give functionality and vitality to the library exterior. Tables will double as game boards for dominoes, chess, etc. Decorating the walkway floor with stripes and milestone markers will invite the community to take laps around the building, furthering the library and city’s goal of empowering the residents of Hialeah to lead healthy lifestyles. The addition of a Free Little Library along with a gathering area will create a portable reading room atmosphere to encourage and provide an opportunity for reading beyond the library doors.
properties.details: The walkway will repurpose and activate the library’s exterior by creating an area where the community can socialize, relax, exercise, and read. The community will have the freedom to use the space creatively with the added benefit of the library’s Wi-Fi extending to this exterior area. These additions will beautify the library and breathe new life into it. Commuters and the general public will see this new movement surrounding the library and feel invited and more at ease to sit, talk, walk, and relax a spell among their fellow neighbors.
properties.submitter_name: Hialeah Public Libraries and the Coipel Family
properties.title: Library in Motion and Domino Park

properties.description: to work with the city. developers, planners/land owners to install an urban food forest corridor. Food forests mimic ecosystems using edible and useful plants. This will provide an incredible edible civic landscape for any resident or visitor to forage on. It will also help beautify the neighborhood and encourage healthy eating, positive gathering spaces and generate more community, living soil, clean water and air, and habitat for urban wildlife.
properties.details:
could attain food security and have access to healthy foods, right in their neighborhood.

Overtown is likely the next Miami neighborhood to experience revitalization, but this time organized around food. MDC has their culinary program there.
