There are several new farm-to-table restaurants planned. And it happens to be one of the most food insecure neighborhoods in Miami. Food is a basic human right.

Gentrification doesn't help everyone. We need new economic development models that won't displace current residents, while allowing for the revitalization to occur. Both are possible, but creating meaningful livelihoods around such basic things as food. This project is a first step in that direction.
properties.title: Overtown FoodScape

properties.description: Our idea is to improve the M-Path below Metrorail before and after The Underline is built. The Underline has a unique challenge; it limits the use of permanent structures that could provide much-needed shade along the corridor.  We will create a highly visible, annual architectural competition for a temporary shade structure to be added to the MPath/ Underline project. The annual competition will be run through the University of Miami’s School of Architecture; and we will build and install the first selected design.  Our goal is to enhance public open space in the city by creating an iconic structure to be enjoyed by locals and tourists alike.
properties.details: Architectural competitions are rare in our community.  We are excited to offer a high-profile architectural event that brings attention and purpose to the future Underline while spotlighting design excellence in Miami.  A similar initiative: the Serpentine Gallery Pavilion in Hyde Park, London, is one of the most exciting architectural events in the world. Likewise, The Underline Pavilion competition would be an architectural beacon each year, offering much-needed shade structures for Underline visitors and users.
properties.submitter_name: University of Miami School of Architecture
properties.title: The Underline Pavilion

properties.description: The TOML seeks to transform the Par 3 Golf Course, located on the east side of the Palmetto Expressway and south of NW 154th Street, into Miami Lakes Par 3 Central Park. The 32-acre parcel of land, known as the Par 3 Golf Course, was acquired by the Town through a donation from The Graham Companies. Originally opened in 1963, the 18-hole Par 3 Course is located within prime gathering space of Don Shula’s Resort. Our vision is to convert the Par 3 Course into a multi-use central park. This Idea would benefit the recreationally underserved residential community with a unique gathering space, allowing Miami residents to engage at a momentous golf course transformed into a vibrant central park.
properties.details: Par 3 Golf Course is surrounded by apartments, condominiums, villas, hotels, and restaurants. Thus, this Park would be an excellent gathering space for Miamians. Proposed amenities and activities for people to enjoy include walking, jogging, biking, bird watching, sunbathing, and hiking; fitness station; kids play area; botanical gardens; butterfly garden; enhanced landscaping; picnic shelters; and a park and ride parking lot for transit. Strong evidence shows, when people have access to parks and contact with the natural world, their physical and psychological health is improved. The availability of parks is an important quality-of-life factor. This Idea would make Miami better by providing vibrant public green and recreational space.
properties.title: Miami Lakes Par 3 Central Park

properties.description: Wagner Creek, an important arm of Miami River, winds through downtown Miami and the heart of the city’s health district. Once considered the state’s grimiest waters, the creek is on the mend, with cleanup efforts now underway. But the health district—an area that supports over 100,000 people from all walks of life and houses the nation’s second largest concentration of healthcare facilities—lacks inviting green spaces. There are no trees for shade or grassy areas for people to enjoy, and the abundance of concrete only worsens flooding and pollution issues. Our plan is to create beautiful natural areas along the creek—resilient spaces that allow people to connect with nature, support wildlife, and keep residents safe by reducing flooding.
properties.details: Not only will greenery along Wagner Creek make Miami more beautiful, but it will also improve resilience to climate change, and promote public health and wellbeing. By giving the people who work, live and visit here better access to outdoor spaces they can relax and have fun in, these green spaces will support the city’s efforts to be one of the Rockefeller Foundation’s 100 Resilient Cities. Natural areas along the creek will help absorb storm waters that contribute to Miami’s persistent flooding issues and worsen pollution. So, the creek and other waterways will remain clean while Miami’s residents, homes and businesses are kept out of harm’s way. Miami’s wildlife will benefit too—with more habitat, birds and other wildlife can thrive.
properties.title: Resilient Solutions: Putting the “Health” in Miami’s Health District

properties.description: Create a parklet out of a parking space in East Little Havana (ELH) residential area. A parklet is a low-cost, high-impact urban oasis created out of parking spaces (asphalt). ELH has virtually no open space. This parklet would create an open space (to play dominoes) in a densely populated area that lacks gathering spaces. Civic pride can be strengthened through the simple joy of a safe, welcoming place carved from the intensity of the city.
properties.details: Have a gathering place in the dense urban neighborhood lacking on open space. Diversity, density and proximity to jobs are East Little Havana’s strengths. But all those people have very few places to gather to play dominoes, discuss politics and rest their bones on comfortable chairs. This parklet is for the locals, away from the tourists of Calle8. Separated from traffic, raised above street level to connect to the existing sidewalk, this small grouping of tables and chairs can be the start of something big – an emphasis on livability in East Little Havana.
properties.title: La Terracita

properties.description: I have noticed that most parks do not have recycling bins (or enough of them). My idea is for each park in Miami Dade to have recycling bins in the shape of animals. My vision is to have three large containers. There would be a bin for plastic, paper, and glass. The bin for the plastic would be Danny the Dolphin. The bin for the paper could be Alejandro the Alligator and the bin for the glass could be Francois the Flamingo. (Notice how the names are in the three main languages in Miami Dade: English, Spanish, and Creole).
properties.details: This would be a fun way to recycle, especially for kids. They would love to put an empty water bottle into the mouth of a dolphin. The goal is for people to want to recycle. Not only will this idea help to eliminate litter but it will help teach kids to recycle.
properties.title: Noah's A.R.C. (Animal Recycling Containers)

properties.description:
Biscayne Boulevard from SE 1st St to NE 5th St currently features 8 vehicular lanes and interior parking bays.  This is extremely valuable space is underutilized and creates a pedestrian access “barrier” towards the Bay.   Our idea is to temporarily transform three of these pods into activated people spaces and promote a 24/7 livable city for users of all ages.

Pod 1 will “Entertain” by creating an outdoor lounge for movies under the stars, live music, food trucks and video projections.  Pod 2 will foster a “Play” area to provide for children and families with playground, shaded viewing areas and potentially a mini-dog park.  Finally, Pod 3 will "Escape”  with shaded/landscaped reading nooks, a pop-up coffee stand, and programmed yoga.
properties.details:
Downtown Miami suffers greatly from a lack of pedestrian-friendly places to meet, gather, interact, relax and enjoy; and this situation is exacerbated at nighttime.  Therefore, Biscayne Green will provide recreational and passive amenities for residents of all ages and user types, both day and night.   

We will work with FDOT, MDC, MPA and the City to acquire the parking bays, as well as design, install, service, secure, break-down, and fund the entire demonstration project for one month (and donate materials thereafter).  The end goal is to showcase the kind of urban environment people desire, prove that there is a demand for these spaces, and generate the continuous momentum to a point where they can be implemented permanently.
properties.title: Biscayne Green Demonstration Project

properties.description:
Our idea, a temporary environmental art installation along a confusing section of the Baywalk, intends to generate discussion and action towards a permanently improved waterfront trail in Downtown Miami, increasing use by pedestrians and cyclists. A low cost, street-scale installation can attract and guide more people to the existing unmarked, underutilized path that runs between Bayside Marketplace and American Airlines Arena, on land owned by the City, County and State.
Repurposed Melaleuca tree trunks will be painted pink and “planted” vertically to reflect the threat of invasive species. Silhouettes of birds in flight, and blue circles painted beneath each “tree”, will show the shade and support that can be created.
properties.details:
Envision a better waterfront for recreation and alternative transportation in an area that is hidden, blighted and difficult to access. It will attract people to the water and guide them, engage them in an interactive space, offer environmental education and provide a snapshot of what the waterfront COULD be.

This project is a partnership among the Miami Parking Authority, PAMM, ArquitectonicaGeo and Melissa Hege City Planning. It is endorsed by Miami District 2 Commissioner and DDA Chair Ken Russell, County Commissioner Audrey Edmonson, The Nature Conservancy, Bayside Marketplace and Bayfront Park Management Trust. Additional education opportunities in partnership with PAMM and their second Saturdays children’s and teen program.
properties.title: Baywalk Pop-up Installation: Migration

properties.description:
We want to transform the green space and the empty parking space outside the Allapattah Library into a fun, colorful space that invites kids and their parents to read and enjoy story telling. Key features are:

- The facade of the building painted with chalk paint for drawing and writing. 
- Painting the underused pavement with bright colors in vibrant patterns (painted by the community).
- Building up the grass surface as a ground mounds to sit, relax, read and listen.
-Free Wi-Fi for media learning events and sharing. 
-Making use of the large tree for shade and the use of a hammock.
properties.details:
We think reading is fun! Story telling is fun! For many people libraries are an amazing public service that are often neglected and we think its a good idea to reconnect people to libraries so kids (and adults alike) can read, share, play and make new friends.  

It's also very close to the Miami Jackson Senior High School and it would be great to involve students to help paint and make the space their own.
properties.title: Story Telling Garden at the Allapattah Library

properties.description:
With this project, Miamians and visitors of Paul Walker, Kennedy, Grapeland and Margaret Pace Park can enjoy a Smart Bench where they can gather, sit, relax, and charge their mobile devices.  A Smart Bench is a new technology powered by solar energy to provide mobile device charging. The Smart Bench serves a multi-faceted purpose—seating, comfort and gathering space.

Two people can charge their mobile devices at a time, but the bench has room for more people to sit and relax.  Great public spaces contribute to community health and this project contributes to the social and environmental health of the community. This comfortable space is an extension of the community where social exchanges take place and cultures mix.
properties.details:
This project will create public comfort with new technology to enhance lifestyles of Miamians and Paul Walker, Kennedy, Grapeland and Margaret Pace Park visitors. The Smart Benches in these parks will give Miamians and tourists convenience of a mobile charging device in our beautiful parks and invite them to enjoy our parks longer.  

The solar powered Smart Bench is a conversation item that is attractive, innovative, environmentally-friendly and brings people together socially. Miami is fast moving, but also has vibrant parks. This project combines the fast-paced, mobile-friendly elements of Miami with the social, relaxing elements that vibrant public spaces like these four parks, provide.
properties.title: Smart Benches for City of Miami Parks

properties.description: In Southeast Hialeah, nestled between the busiest Home Depot in the city and the Historic Market Station, is a ramp that leads to nowhere. The ramp sits in front of the tri-rail and is the last stop before the airport. People who stop here have nothing to do while they wait. The area is not as inviting as it could be considering how much pedestrian traffic it receives. This ramp can be transformed by adding a low cost railing for safety, umbrellas for shade, removable chairs, and tables for comfort.  Directly in front of the ramp is an empty green space that can also be transformed for beautification, making the area an attractive and relaxing space for the public to enjoy.
properties.details: Transforming this area will provide the city with a space for residents to gather and for visitors using public transportation to enjoy while they wait.
properties.title: Hialeah Market Station Square

properties.description: Buskerfest Miami and longtime collaborators Emerge Miami will program Miami's first traveling, outdoor open mic. This uniquely Miami program will feature local musicians, acrobats, theatrical groups, comedians and more in Miami's three Downtown Miami parks: Museum, Bayfront and the newly christened Dan Paul Park on Parcel B. The public can look forward to the best of Miami's homegrown talent in the public spaces that define Downtown Miami.  You may know ULTRA, but the real party is at CULTRA!
properties.details: Miami is blessed with beautiful, iconic parks that are not as lively as we would like. CULTRA will activate all of Downtown Miami's parks, encouraging newcomers to explore and old pals to reconnect with Museum, Bayfront and Dan Paul Parks. CULTRA will provide an opportunity for both emerging and established artists to perform for the local community in an area currently devoid of small to mid-size performing arts venues. The project will also highlight the potential of Parcel B, a piece of neglected land behind American Airlines arena, which was intended to be a public park.
properties.title: CULTRA - Miami's First Outdoor Open Mic

properties.description: A green buffer in front of a parking lot should become a real public green space for downtown Coral Gables' residents and local businesses. This strip of open space could easily be transformed into an area where local workers can have lunch and residents can escape into a sliver of nature. The vast majority of Coral Gables’ parks and open spaces are located in the single-family residential areas of the city. Meanwhile, downtown residents, workers, and visitors have few options for public open space. There are 5 parking spaces directly to the east of the existing grassy area that could also be added to the open space, or used to park food trucks. The small park can serve as a catalyst for creating more public spaces in the downtown area.
properties.details: So that people could relax on benches under the shade trees for residents and near-by businesses to sit and enjoy lunch. The grassy area is also on the future Galiano bike boulevard and would be ideal to offer bike facilities, such as bike racks, a repair station, bike share, water fountain, etc. The gathering space could also increase interactions between downtown residents of adjacent condos; retirees at the nearby senior living facility; and younger people passing by or enjoying lunch.
properties.title: Downtown Coral Gables Community Park

properties.description: This idea is to create an educational garden at the TACOLCY center in Liberty City to teach children and community members about aeroponics. The garden would feature a informational displays related to fundamentals of aeroponic gardening and weekly seminars for community members who want to learn more.
properties.details: This garden would serve 3 purposes: education,  aesthetics, and community building. Community members will learn about building gardening systems and gardening fundamentals. The garden will also serve as a tranquil and beautiful oasis where people can reconnect with nature. Finally, the garden provides a space where community members can meet, learn together and work together on collaborative projects. An added bonus is the potential of increased access to fresh fruits and vegetables.
properties.title: Aeroponic Educational Garden

properties.address: South Beach
properties.description:
Make mile marker signs along the beach for walkers/runners to track their distance without being connected to their phone/internet. 

These cost effective signs could also be easily reproduced and placed in parks through out Miami.
properties.details:
These mile markers would allow fitness enthusiasts to enjoy their surroundings and achieve their goals at the same time. 

This installation would also provide opportunities for people to engage with one another, therefore building a stronger connection within the health and wellness community.
properties.title: Mark Your Miles Miami!

properties.address: North Shore Open Space Park
properties.description: North Shore Open Space Park is a natural oasis for beach goers. Miami Music Club will curate a series of events with local and national underground musicians, artists, and dancers, whose work will turn the park into a temporary art space. Dubbed MMC by the Sea, the first volume took place in November, 2016, in collaboration with the Common Field national arts convening. For these events, held at the park’s low-cost rental pavilions, artists will be asked to create site-specific sound and performance works, creating a dialogue about the park itself and its future. The series will advocate for responsible environmental stewardship, and will bring greater attention to the park across a diverse community of cultural producers and audiences.
properties.details: MMC by the Sea will invite diverse communities to experience music and performance—the kind that is normally relegated to museums, galleries and music venues—in an outdoor space of sand dunes, sea grape trees, and breaking surf (free of charge). It will provide a platform for different, critically-engaged communities to come together while encouraging thoughtful meditation on the bridges between culture and nature. The performances will promote responsible use and appreciation for Miami’s parks and beaches, while activating them in ways Miami audiences have rarely seen. MMC by the Sea will offer a site for sonic contemplation and reflection on the natural beauty and history of South Florida, coupled with a lovely day at the beach.
properties.title: MMC by the Sea

properties.address: Doral Central Park, City of Doral
properties.description:
Our idea is to educate children and adults about bike and street safety in general by allowing the children to "drive" in a scale city complete with intersections, traffic lights, pedestrian crossings, parking spots, etc.
This will bring community involvement while reinforcing traffic rules (so necessary in our cities), healthy and fitness interaction with police that will help our kids grow to become responsible citizens.
Improve overall driving conditions in our city by getting our children the knowledge of traffic rules since they are young, this will enable them to interact with adults in their daily commutes.
properties.details:
So that children can practice "driving", walking, biking in a safe manner on a scale model of an actual street community, complete with traffic signs, traffic lights, intersections, police officers, etc. 
Children will be able to learn traffic rules and get a "driver's license" prior to being allowed to "drive" in our "Traffic Park streets".
We will generate community unity and safety awareness in a safe environment that will offer an educational experience full of fun and excitement.
properties.organization: City of Doral Parks and Police 4Kids Foundation
properties.title: Traffic Park

properties.address: 18th St & Purdy Avenue, Miami Beach, FL 33139
properties.description: ...is to create a "park hopper" scavenger hunt via a kayak tour open to the public.  Funds from The Miami Foundation would support the creation and installation of engaging signage with creative, environmentally-focused "clues," which will lead curious kayak rowers from Maurice Gibb Park's public kayak launch in South Beach and guide them through Miami Beach's intracoastal waterway system (Biscayne Bay, Collins Canal, and Indian Creek), as well as from park-to-park and even to Monument Island and Belle Isle.  The project would also utilize the City of Miami Beach's "Resiliency Tour" app, which is currently under development and will electronically showcase the community's magnificent parks and aquatic ecosystem.
properties.details: ...actively access Miami Beach's parks via an underutilized transportation alternative system (our community's waterways) in an exciting and adventurous way, as well as connect them to our community's diverse ecosystem, which includes mangroves, manatees, dolphins, and so much more!
properties.title: Park Hopper Scavenger Hunt and Kayak Tour via Miami Beach's Waterways

properties.address: Biscayne National Park, 9700 SW 328 Street, Homestead FL 33033
properties.description:
Host more citizenship ceremonies in South Florida’s national parks. What better way to welcome new citizens to the USA and make them feel like true Americans than to administer the oath of citizenship in one of our national parks – a symbol of what’s best about this country and its democratic ideals.

Citizenship ceremonies could be held outdoors under a tent in Biscayne National Park with a waterfront view of Biscayne Bay, or trail-side in Everglades National Park with an audience of alligators, egrets and great blue herons.
properties.details:
On the day of the ceremony, new citizens could arrive early with their families to meet a park ranger and take a tour. Or they could stay late to explore the park on their own. 

After the ceremony, all new citizens would receive an “ownership” manual describing the national park system and South Florida’s four national parks, with a voucher to return with their family anytime.
properties.title: Citizenship Ceremonies in Miami's National Parks

properties.address: West End, Kendall
properties.description: Is to create the West End Ciclovia, an event where 147nd Ave is closed for vehicular traffic somewhere between 120st and 88st, during a set time of the day, and transformed into a linear walking space, bike trail, and farmer's market. The path will feature stops with vendors and music, lining the shaded stretches of setbacks at one side of the road. The event can culminate at Kendale Lakes Park.
properties.details: Come together in one big event and discover that the biking activity in this area is stronger than it may seem. The West End is home to over 200,000 people! A majority of which live in multi-generational households. Our community craves these events, and when given the chance, we support them! The Ciclovia will create a stronger, more aware community rallying together toward shared interests such as promoting other events and improving rider safety. Additionally, this stretch of road is already home to informal "side-of-the-road" vending of fresh local produce and flowers. The event will encourage their legitimization during set events, making it safer. Lastly, the event is for our families to share a fun and healthy activity together!
properties.title: The West End Ciclovia

properties.address: 4280 SW 60th Ct
properties.description: South Miami Park only has one current entry on the east side.  This means that the park is typically only accessible by car, even for people who live right next to the park  on the north and west side.   Someone living right on the northwest corner of the park has to walk 1/2 mile to reach the car accessilbe entry.  A new pedestrian entry to the park would make the park much more accessible.
properties.details: So people that people who live near the park can access the park in their neighborhood without driving to it.
properties.title: New South Miami Park Entry

properties.address: I added Larry and Penny Thompson park but really these could, and should go in numerous spots around the city!
properties.description:
is to provide urban hives across the city to encourage a declining honeybee population to flourish in Miami-Dade.  Honeybees pollinate agricultural and horticultural crops, helping us sustain crops (specifically tropical fruit trees!) while supporting beautiful, flowering landscapes. They also could provide residents with honey! 

These hives could be placed in any area in Miami but would ideally be in places close to water sources. The hives could be supplemented by the natural landscape or could have tropical fruit trees and native flowering plants planted around them. This would not only beautify the area but would help provide sustenance for the bees.
properties.details:
enjoy honey made in their neighborhood! Promote pollinators in agricultural and horticultural areas! Create opportunities for the community to learn about this incredible insect! Inspire respect towards our environment!
 
So many other large cities have embraced urban beekeeping, to the benefit of their communities. Allowing for hives to be placed in locations across Miami-Dade will help us start to rebuild the colonies of bees, millions of which were killed when Miami was being sprayed to eradicate Zika. I can envision public courses in beekeeping taking place on the weekend, with learning opportunities for maintaining a hive, harvesting honey, understanding the different types of bee, etc.
properties.title: Public Hives

properties.address: 550 NW 42nd Avenue, Miami 33126
properties.description:
Flagami is an unrecognized (and undiscovered) neighborhood close to the MIA airport with 50,000 low-income residents, few family activities and limited fresh food availability. Through the collaborative ideas of multiple partners (Big Brothers Big Sisters, Hope for Miami, Urban Oasis Project, Unconventional) we have an outdoor location for these activities:
•	A monthly Farmer’s Market from Urban Oasis Project 
•	Youth Murals: painting on the outdoor walls under the supervision of professional artists from Unconventional 
•	Live music and youth performances
•	Planting small garden plots of herbs and vegetables 
•	Constructing a corner reflection garden with seating, art and a free little library.
properties.details:
•	Have an outdoor gathering place for families within walking distance with fresh foods, arts & literacy activities and music to enhance their quality of life. 
•	Double the value of food stamp benefits for fresh produce at the Farmer’s Market and eat better quality healthy foods. 
•	Children will have opportunities for artistic expression painting the murals and creating art for the benefit of the whole neighborhood.
•	The outdoor space will become a WALKABLE local gathering place with family-friendly activities.
•	Connect with their neighbors and new services available offer by the area non-profit partners.
•	Relax and take reflection breaks at any time in the outdoor garden.
properties.submitter_name: Hope for Miami & Big Brothers Big Sisters
properties.title: Flagami Fresh+Art

properties.address: 1300 Biscayne Blvd.
properties.description: A freestyle summer breakin’ showdown for Miami street dancers outside the Adrienne Arsht Center, with local crews competing for a chance to perform later in the season on the main stage of the 2,200-seat Knight Concert Hall. The free outdoor event will charge one of downtown Miami’s public spaces with hip hop moves and music as some of the city’s best dance crews headspin their way into a professional contract.
properties.details: Show off their power moves or watch others perform in a come-together summer moment celebrating Miami’s unique hip-hop culture. Help judges pick the best in our own backyard while turning a still-developing section of Miami into an epic dance-off space.
properties.title: Breakin’ Convention Miami Block Party

properties.address: 2605 NE 135th St. - North Miami, 33181
properties.description:
Greenway intersects Blueway! 
ACE Preserve is part the Oleta Link. Its a Nature Preserve needing TLC to reach its potential.
Pause your bike commute to enjoy nature, with birds, butterflies, rays, and maybe even a manatee…
We’ll make ACE a better Path & Preserve by adding native habitat and enhancements, & connecting it with the Blueway: 
Shade Trees, Nature Trails, Bike Rack, Paddlecraft Launch, Owl Boxes or Osprey Platforms, Park Benches, Educational Signs, The Preserve Commons... 
UPG has been working for 4 years with local residents and stakeholders… and we want to do more to engage the community in being agents of change: Habitat Planting & Stewardship, Nature Walks, Kids Education.
See link for video & photos.
properties.details:
Shade Trees enhance walking and biking. 
Nature Trails allow walkers to delve into different habitats, and provide 2 options to the paved path.
Bike Rack invites cyclists to explore Nature. 
Paddlecraft Launch connects the Greenway to Biscayne Bay, our ultimate Blueway. 
Owl Boxes or Osprey Platforms encourage raptors to make a family. 
Park Benches allow tired travelers – especially our oldest and youngest – to rest along their journeys, and observe nature and vistas. 
Interpretive & Educational Signs engage the public in understanding habitat/wildlife interactions and the impact of community on the projects. 
The Preserve Commons invites individuals and groups to practice meditation, yoga, tai chi and other activities in the Preserve.
properties.title: ACE Preserve Project Greenway Blueway & Habitat

properties.address: This project will be located at 207 NE 59th Street, Miami, FL 33137 in the Little Haiti neighborhood.
properties.description: With this project, residents and visitors can enjoy a revitalized public space in Miami’s culturally-rich Little Haiti. This project will activate a currently empty lot located at 207 NE 59th Street in Little Haiti, temporarily transforming it into a pop-up miniature golf course. It will be a 9 hole, miniature golf course designed with Caribbean motifs by local artists in the community, and will be available for 3 months, Mondays-Saturdays 10AM-4PM. The project site will be located in the heart of Little Haiti so that it is easily accessible to the entire community. The Little Haiti neighborhood is deeply invested in the future of its community, and residents are eager to transform public spaces into vibrant gathering spaces.
properties.details: This public space pop-up will provide a family-friendly past time for the Little Haiti community and safe space for children and families to gather and play. As an urban area, Miami needs creative public space transformations like this project, to continually revitalize communities. Using local Little Haiti artists to help design the mini golf course in Caribbean theme will capitalize on the strong sense of ownership that the Miami community displays in its neighborhoods. This project will enhance the recent activation of the Caribbean Marketplace and the new Mache (traditional Haitian open air market) taking place every Saturday from 10AM-4PM, so Miamians and visitors can enjoy both the project and the cultural events in Little Haiti.
properties.submitter_name: City of Miami Little Haiti Cultural Center
properties.title: Pop-Up Mini Golf: Revitalizing Little Haiti

properties.address: 20th St and NW 7th Avenue
properties.description: is to use colorful LED lighting to brighten/ beautify the NW 20th Street underpass, making it safer and more appealing for pedestrians and bikers. In this area, I-95 serves as a significant barrier between Wynwood and Overtown; NW 20th Street is one of the few connecting streets, yet the underpass at I-95 is a dark and unpleasant experience for pedestrians. However, with the imminent addition of a CitiBikes stand at Converge Miami and the forthcoming addition of pedestrian crosswalks thanks to a collaboration with Street Plans Collective, this corner will become more transitable and engaging.  Lighting the underpass will encourage more pedestrian activity across these disconnected neighborhoods.
properties.details: walk along the NW 20th St underpass safely and comfortably, while enjoying a colorful light display. The underpass lighting will help re-connect the communities on either side of I-95 by increasing the flow of pedestrians and bikers through this area who are traveling between home, work, school, health services, recreation and retail destinations. As Converge Miami grows as an entrepreneurial center, more startups, students, and researchers will populate this area. If, however, the streets surrounding the building remain inhospitable to pedestrians, they will remain siloed and be less likely to engage with the neighborhood. The objective of the underpass project is to dovetail with other additions to incentivize walking and biking.
properties.title: Lighting the Way: Connecting Overtown and Wynwood

properties.address: NW 60th St & 19th Ave
properties.description: Our names our Annie St. Juste &  Lanston Williams and we live in the Annie Coleman public housing units off NW 60th St. in Liberty City. In our community unlike most; when the sun goes down it is dark or pitch black. We have 5 children who are enrolled in Miami Children’s Initiative's program at Charles Drew. We would love to have lights in our walkways as it gets extremely dark all around our area. When the sun goes down we are a afraid because of how dark it gets, especially walking with young children. There are three specific pathways we would like to be lit. One pathway links NW 60th St., where our kids walk from school, to NW 62nd St. One Pathway goes to our home through the Miami Children's Initiative's Memorial Garden. The final are
properties.details: We want for our children and our neighbors to be able to have walkways where you don’t have to look over your shoulders every minute. It’s so dark in our neighborhood that people go inside as soon as the sun goes down and the wrong people are attracted to our community and engage in criminal activities. We believe that with added lights it will not only make our walkways to the park and home safer but will allow our children to play outside longer and enjoy all the benefits of MCI’s playground and the basketball court. Additionally, when we have to stay late at school for parent nights we do not want to be fearful of walking back home. These light will not only make it safe for our family but the entire community as a whole.
properties.title: Liberty City Lights

properties.address: SW 152 Street (Coral Reef Drive) at SW 107 Court and SW 152 Terrace
properties.description:
My idea is to transform a highly used but oft neglected pedestrian cut-through into a welcoming, visually appealing, safe feeling, community connecting, source of resident pride in my neighborhood. The pathway currently looks like a vacant lot: overgrown grass & trees, poor lighting, and dumped garbage. It is ugly and feels unsafe.

SW 152 St. bisects Richmond Heights and Palmetto Estates neighborhoods with a concrete wall forming a mile-long barrier on the street’s south side from SW 112 Ave. to Fairway Heights Blvd. The cut-through, located halfway between these points at SW 107 Court and SW 152 Terrace, serves as the sole pedestrian access point to Colonial Drive Park, bus stops on 152 St., and between the residents of each community.
properties.details:
Transforming the cut-through into a welcoming and safe public space would provide opportunities for residents within each neighborhood to connect with one another and to their communities as they enter and exit Palmetto Estates whether on their way to the park, to public transportation, to visit with friends/family, or to exercise (i.e., jogging, bicycling, dog walking, etc.). 

- Community ‘maintenance’ crew(s)
- Community bulletin board
- Free book kiosk
- Public piano
- Checkers/chess table
- Water bottle refill station
- Artful and art-filled walkway (murals, mosaics, etc.)
- Benches
- Attractive landscaping
- Lighting
- Waste receptacles
properties.title: Cutting-through, Connecting Communities

properties.address: Virginia Key North Point Trails - Virginia Key, FL
properties.description: 7 years ago, the City of Miami turned over the North Point area to Bernard Riviere and his group of volunteers (22,000 hours).The 50 acre park (100% funded by the club) boasts 7.8 miles of adaptive, beginner, intermediate and expert trails. We would like to incorporate a skills area, enhance adaptive trails and complete expansion of trails over the remaining five acres of usable land. We are in dire need of new equipment and materials.  We would like to add an all-terrain vehicle to our fleet, we are currently covering the 50 acres with a golf cart which is in need of repair.  The cart is also used to respond to emergencies and transport volunteers to work sites.VKBC is proud to give back to the community - thank you for your consideration.
properties.title: Enhancement of Virginia Key North Point Trails

properties.address: Royal Road's waterfront cul-de-sac in Coconut Grove
properties.description: Convert the City-owned Right of Way at the end of Coconut Grove’s Royal Rd. to a designated mini-park.  Grass, landscaping and shade trees will be planted. Benches, a picnic table, trash cans, and a bicycle rack will be installed.
properties.details: Fish, picnic, launch kayaks, and enjoy views of Biscayne Bay. Despite Coconut Grove’s miles of shoreline, many local residents -- especially from the less advantaged Village West neighborhood just a few blocks away -- have little access to the water. The dead end of Royal Rd. has served this function for decades, as a rough and informal water-access point for many of these nearby families. Although the City maintains the Right of Way property, it is not among Miami’s parks inventory and does not receive capital funding for upkeep and improvements.
properties.title: Big Hill Park

properties.address: MDC InterAmerican Campus. Little Havana,  627 SW 27th Avenue.  NW Corner of SW 25th Avenue and SW 6th Street
properties.description: At the intersection of 5 streets next to the MDC campus, UrbanaSpace will visually invite the public into both the green buffer placed between the parking lot and the street (after its transformation into a Pine Rockland) and a ¼ mile sidewalk circling the flat lot.  UrbanaSpace will be the starting point for those in the community--75,000 residents and 5,000 students--who want a safe place to walk or enjoy a natural environment.  An aesthetically designed area with seating will offer the community an opportunity to learn about the beauty and history of native habitats in South Florida.  Inspirational messages and signage will be designed by an artist with the community to encourage walking, learning, and a sense of belonging to nature.
properties.details: Miami needs to create urban opportunities for the community to gather in natural surroundings where they live and work.  This is especially true in heavily paved areas like Little Havana.  Park space and available walking paths are limited and often not nearby enough for locals to access. Instead, UrbanaSpace offers a way to repurpose common space differently to reconnect the community to nature. Greenery in parking lots is often used as decoration. In UrbanaSpace, greenery is used to engage and educate.  UrbanaSpace can demo what’s possible for the many flat lots around Miami.  When people have a chance to gather in a natural environment that is local, opportunities arise for knowing one another and knowing the benefits of nature.
properties.title: UrbanaSpace:  A Little Corner of Happy and a ¼ Mile of Healthy Right in Little Havana

properties.address: Williams Park: 1717 NW 5 Avenue Miami, FL 33136
properties.description:
WiFi @ Williams Park brings provides free wifi and programming to improve digital access for youth and  maximize the use of the park to support 21st Century skills development.
Through strategic partnerships, with Urban Impact, South Florida CARES and the City of Miami Parks and other partners, we will integrate wifi enabled tech hubs into the existing built environment. Specifically, PCO will pilot in William Park, retrofitting existing infrastructure with solar powered charging stations, marked by innovative art activations and digital literacy programming. PCO will amplify existing CARES' programs at Williams Park with digital competencies, which is essential to generating economic development and cultivating future tech talent.
properties.details: PCO re-imagines urban spaces (parks) to serve a multiplicity of needs for the end users by increasing internet accessibility.  Expanding internet access to target urban areas will increase youth residents’ access to information through digital interfaces and to provide educational resources as a technology onramp provider.  Youth can explore technology in common spaces outside, negating the isolating stereotypes associated with technology. Narrowing the technological inequality gap is the ultimate goal of this project. Youth will have reliable internet access for homework and educational purposes in addition to all community members have greater access to social services, employment opportunities, and educational tools.
properties.title: Wi-Fi @ Williams Park (a pilot of the Park Connect @ Overtown Initiative)

properties.address: Tamiami Park - 11201 SW 24th St, Miami, FL 33165
properties.description:
The Miami FC Foundation will transform the underutilized street hockey rink at Tamiami Park into a Mini-Pitch on which small-sided football (soccer) games can be played.
*Small-sided football matches are any played with teams of less than 11 a side.
Mini-Pitches have been proven to have a positive impact on recreational participation by giving more people across all categories the opportunity to play the game. Simply put, Mini-Pitches support informal play, making the game accessible to everyone who has an interest, including key target groups who may not feel included - individuals with disabilities, younger age groups, and girls.
The Mini-Pitch will also be used as a host site for other inclusive health & wellness programming.
properties.details:
As the world's most popular sport, football has the unique opportunity to unite Miami's diverse populace in a way that no other sport can. Football is inclusive by nature. Players don't need special equipment to play; just a ball and a playing field - and we have learned that people are already using the hockey rink for this purpose. 
Receiving this grant will allow us to enhance the experience by creating a more safe and welcoming place for an even greater number of people to engage: new relationships will be 
developed as people meet and take part in impromptu "pick-up" games; use of the Mini-Pitch will inspire activity that reinforces play as a vital component of a healthy lifestyle.
properties.title: Futbol For All: Transforming Tamiami Park's Street Hockey Rink into a Small Sided Soccer Mini-Pitch

properties.address: 60 E 4 Street
properties.description: A litle history... the Flagler Cottage is on a City-owned lot deemed Ft. Dallas Park, on the north side of the Miami River in downtown.  The Park is fenced and locked, the historic Flagler Cottage  needs repair and it is off limits to all.  The Flagler Cottage is the only remaining building building that evidences Henry Flagler's existence in Miami - amazing given the fact he basically put Miami on the map by bringing the railroad here!  Through a creative partnership with the City and private companies, Dade Heritage Trust can restore and interpret the building, open it to the public and create a cafe and bike rental shop right on the Miami River Greenway - an awesome and seldom used urban bike and pedestrian trail along the Miami River.
properties.details: By creating the Flagler Cottage Cafe and Bike Rental, the public will have access to an historic building and greenspace on the Miami River.  Visitors will get to know the Miami River Greenway as part of a transit trail along both banks of the Miami River and be encouraged to use the Greenway via bike or foot.  In addition, the history of the railroad in Miami and Henry Flagler's vast influence on the development Miami could be presented inside the historic Cottage which can also serve as a visitors center with information about Miami. Long-term,  people that also envision the Flagler Cottage property as a water-taxi stop.  So visitors to the site:  learn about history at a restored historic site, learn about an urban trail, bike and walk!
properties.title: Flagler Cottage Cafe and Bike Rental on the Miami River
